content.description: (The following is taken from Paul Bernard's great book "Rock Climbs of Northeast California").Start as for Unknown Left. Go up and right, following the right hand line of bolts. Fun and well protected. Don't get confused by the close by bolts to the left!

(The following is taken from Paul Bernard's great book "Rock Climbs of Northeast California"). Find a tree 15' off the ground. Climb 3rd class junk to base of tree and start of climb. Follow the line up past 5 bolts on an increasingly steep face.
content.location: The second from the left line, look for 2 vertical lines of 5 bolts. This is the left hand line.

content.description: Worth the walk over from the Peapod area. A quick easy line up 7 bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location: To the right of the dirty flaring chimney. Do not confuse this line (5.8) and the other nearby 7 bolt line (C.F., 5.11.c)! Easy to see one is steep; this one is full of big holds, less steep, etc.

content.description: The farthest left line at the rock band, look for a dirty, broken series of cracks in a right facing semi-dihedral. Loose rock. Bring slings to belay from tree at top. Walk off left. Watch out for rock fall onto your belayer.
content.location: The farthest left line at the rock band, look for a dirty, broken series of cracks in a right facing semi-dihedral.

content.description: Anyone for a dirty rotten chimney? With loose rock and lousy pro? You found it! Hard for the grade because of the dirt and loose rock.
content.location: Scramble up the 3rd class mess 15' towards a small tree, move right as soon as you can into a flaring dirty open chimney.

content.description: Choose fists or fingers, both head into a short flare/pod/chimney eases up into a nice cruise to the tree at the top.
content.location: Just of the right of the easier 7 bolt line, look for the chimney 15 feet up.
